results.headline: Bad Deathbed Advice, Indeed
results.summary_short: In “Charlie Countryman,” a young American travels whimsically to Romania, where he falls in love with a tough young woman married to a gangster.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Charlie Countryman

results.headline: A Scrapbook of a Memorable Night for Rock
results.summary_short: The documentary “12-12-12” goes behind the scenes at the Concert for Sandy Relief, with Bruce Springsteen, the Rolling Stones and Kanye West.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 12-12-12

results.headline: Factory Farming, From an Animal Point of View
results.summary_short: “Speciesism,” a documentary written and directed by Mark Devries, explores animal rights and factory farms.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Speciesism: The Movie

results.headline: A Dancer Tries Out Many Moves
results.summary_short: A dancer juggles a busy love life in “Sex, Love & Salsa.”

results.display_title: Ilya and Emilia Kabakov: Enter Here
results.headline: Reworking Their Soviet Past
results.summary_short: “Ilya and Emilia Kabakov: Enter Here” is a portrait of the two artists on the occasion of their return to the former Soviet Union for a string of exhibitions of their work in Moscow.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ilya and Emilia Kabakov: Enter Here

results.headline: In Iowa, but Dreaming of D.C.
results.summary_short: “Caucus,” an A. J. Schnack documentary, chronicles the Republican nominating contest in Iowa in 2012.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Caucus

results.headline: A Major University and How It Works
results.summary_short: Frederick Wiseman’s documentary “At Berkeley” takes viewers into the classrooms and the broad campus life of a well-functioning university.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of At Berkeley

results.headline: The Hammer Resurgent
results.summary_short: “Thor: The Dark World” repackages the thunder god as an alien superhero played by Chris Hemsworth.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Thor: The Dark World

results.headline: In Soulful Devotion, Glimmers of Doom
results.summary_short: The animated film “The Wind Rises,” which Hayao Miyazaki says will be his last, is a poetic yet somber depiction of Jiro Horikoshi as a young warplane designer.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Wind Rises

results.headline: Even One Win Can Mean Everything
results.summary_short: “Medora,” directed by Andrew Cohn and Davy Rothbart, views the decline of small-town America through the eyes of a high school basketball team in Indiana.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Medora

results.headline: Like an Outlaw-Country Song
results.summary_short: “The Motel Life,” based on a novel by Willy Vlautin, follows two brothers around seedy locales in the West.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Motel Life

results.headline: A Camera Aimed at the Conscience
results.summary_short: A crusading photographer, Jo-Anne McArthur, documents the treatment of animals used for meat, clothes and lab testing in Liz Marshall’s “The Ghosts in Our Machine.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Ghosts in Our Machine

results.headline: A Refuge Found in Pages
results.summary_short: “The Book Thief” reveals how a girl copes during the horrors of adolescence and World War II.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Book Thief

results.headline: He Lost His Titles, but Never His Cool
results.summary_short: A movie shot while Lance Armstrong lied about doping and after he admitted it feels like two movies — a before and after — roughly stitched together.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Armstrong Lie

results.headline: A Poet’s Tempestuous Romance in Brazil
results.summary_short: “Reaching for the Moon,” directed by Bruno Barretto, dramatizes the 1950s affair of Elizabeth Bishop and Lota de Macedo Soares.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Reaching for the Moon

results.headline: Eider Ducks Carry a Chilly Warning
results.summary_short: The director Joel Heath examines the link between hydroelectric power and an endangered Arctic ecosystem in “People of a Feather.”

results.headline: Guns, Chases and Disreputable Pleasures in the City of Light
results.summary_short: In “Paris Countdown,” a freed psychopath goes after the two associates who testified against him.

results.headline: What She’ll Do for a Passport
results.summary_short: An immigrant model/actress gets bad career advice and an F.B.I. interrogation in “L.A. Superheroes: Illegal in Hollywood.”

results.headline: He Can’t Always Live With Himself
results.summary_short: In “It’s Me, It’s Me,” a young salesman meets several duplicates of himself, and doesn’t much like some of them.

results.headline: Young Love, Interrupted by a Nuclear Bomb
results.summary_short: In “How I Live Now,” based on the novel by Meg Rosoff, a surly American teenager finds herself caught in World War III in Britain.
